title: The Acrobatics of 𝖡𝖰𝖯
abstract:
Abstract
One can fix the randomness used by a randomized algorithm, but there is no analogous notion of fixing the quantumness used by a quantum algorithm. Underscoring this fundamental difference, we show that, in the black-box setting, the behavior of quantum
polynomial-time (𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖡𝖰𝖯\mathsf{BQP}) can be remarkably decoupled from that of
classical complexity classes like 𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{NP}.  Specifically:


•

There exists an oracle relative to
which 𝖭𝖯𝖡𝖰𝖯⊄𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖯𝖧not-subset-ofsuperscript𝖭𝖯𝖡𝖰𝖯superscript𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖯𝖧\mathsf{NP}^{\mathsf{BQP}}\not\subset\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{PH}}, resolving a 2005 problem of Fortnow.
As a corollary, there exists an oracle relative to which 𝖯=𝖭𝖯𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{P}=\mathsf{NP} but 𝖡𝖰𝖯≠𝖰𝖢𝖬𝖠𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖰𝖢𝖬𝖠\mathsf{BQP}\neq\mathsf{QCMA}.



•

Conversely, there exists an oracle relative to
which 𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖭𝖯⊄𝖯𝖧𝖡𝖰𝖯not-subset-ofsuperscript𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖭𝖯superscript𝖯𝖧𝖡𝖰𝖯\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{NP}}\not\subset\mathsf{PH}^{\mathsf{BQP}}.



•

Relative to a random oracle, 𝖯𝖯=𝖯𝗈𝗌𝗍𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖯𝖯𝖯𝗈𝗌𝗍𝖡𝖰𝖯\mathsf{PP}=\mathsf{PostBQP} is not contained in the “𝖰𝖬𝖠𝖰𝖬𝖠\mathsf{QMA} hierarchy” 𝖰𝖬𝖠𝖰𝖬𝖠𝖰𝖬𝖠⋯superscript𝖰𝖬𝖠superscript𝖰𝖬𝖠superscript𝖰𝖬𝖠⋯\mathsf{QMA}^{\mathsf{QMA}^{\mathsf{QMA}^{\cdots}}}.



•

Relative to a random oracle, Σk+1𝖯⊄𝖡𝖰𝖯Σk𝖯not-subset-ofsuperscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Σ𝑘1𝖯superscript𝖡𝖰𝖯superscriptsubscriptsans-serif-Σ𝑘𝖯\mathsf{\Sigma}_{k+1}^{\mathsf{P}}\not\subset\mathsf{BQP}^{\mathsf{\Sigma}_{k}^{\mathsf{P}}} for every k𝑘k.



•

There exists an oracle relative to which 𝖡𝖰𝖯=𝖯#​𝖯𝖡𝖰𝖯superscript𝖯#𝖯\mathsf{BQP}=\mathsf{P^{\#P}} and yet 𝖯𝖧𝖯𝖧\mathsf{PH} is infinite.  (By contrast, relative to all oracles, if
𝖭𝖯⊆𝖡𝖯𝖯𝖭𝖯𝖡𝖯𝖯\mathsf{NP}\subseteq\mathsf{BPP}, then 𝖯𝖧𝖯𝖧\mathsf{PH} collapses.)



•

There exists an oracle relative to which 𝖯=𝖭𝖯≠𝖡𝖰𝖯=𝖯#​𝖯𝖯𝖭𝖯𝖡𝖰𝖯superscript𝖯#𝖯\mathsf{P}=\mathsf{NP}\neq\mathsf{BQP}=\mathsf{P}^{\mathsf{\#P}}.



To achieve these results, we build on the 2018 achievement by Raz and Tal of an oracle relative to which 𝖡𝖰𝖯⊄𝖯𝖧not-subset-of𝖡𝖰𝖯𝖯𝖧\mathsf{BQP}\not\subset\mathsf{PH}, and associated results about the Forrelation problem. We also introduce new tools that might be of independent interest. These include a “quantum-aware” version of the random restriction method, a concentration theorem for the block sensitivity of 𝖠𝖢𝟢superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC^{0}} circuits, and a (provable) analogue of the Aaronson-Ambainis Conjecture for sparse oracles.
